ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Chronic subjective tinnitus
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports disabling whistling in the center of the head for over 10 years, causing severe distress and high THI score (72%).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiometry shows bilateral symmetrical mild to severe loss at 3000-8000 Hz, consistent with history of military noise exposure and age.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Depression and anxiety
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient admits to being depressed and agitated due to tinnitus; prescribed Zopiclone for sleep disturbance.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds given the history of noise exposure and tinnitus.
To evaluate middle ear function and rule out conductive pathology.
To assess speech recognition abilities, though not completed in this case due to lack of subjective hearing difficulty.
To quantify the severity of tinnitus and its impact on quality of life.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Assessment reveals a 72-year-old male with disabling central tinnitus and associated distress/depression. Audiometry shows bilateral symmetrical high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (3-8 kHz) with normal low-frequency hearing. Tympanometry is normal. THI score of 72% indicates severe handicap.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral symmetrical mild to severe high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss at 3000-8000 Hz; hearing within normal limits 250-2000 Hz.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Type A bilaterally (normal middle ear pressure, compliance, and ear canal volume).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Not completed because the patient reported no difficulty hearing.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Patient reported some relief with bedside sound generator but tinnitus remains disabling. Fitted with bilateral digital BTE hearing aids (slim-tubes, open domes) configured with two programs: one for tinnitus relief (omni, no NR, low compression kneepoint) and one for speech clarity.

tests.name: Hearing Aid Fitting
tests.result_summary: Fitted with bilateral digital BTEs. Program 1 (Tinnitus): max audibility of soft sounds, NR off, omnidirectional. Program 2 (Speech): NAL-NL1, NR on, adaptive directionality.

proposed_items: Bilateral digital BTE hearing aids with slim-tubes and open domes
Hearing aid program 1: Tinnitus relief (maximize audibility of soft sounds, compression kneepoint ~40 dB SPL, Noise Reduction OFF, Omnidirectional mic)
Hearing aid program 2: Speech recognition (NAL-NL1 targets, Noise Reduction ON, Adaptive Directionality ON)
Bedside digital environmental sound generator or radio for sleep enrichment
Involvement of General Practitioner to monitor general and psychological well-being and medication (Zopiclone)
counseling_actions: Explain tinnitus mechanisms and the role of high-frequency hearing loss in 'starkness' of tinnitus
Counsel on sound enrichment to reduce contrast between tinnitus and background environment
Instruct on use of specific hearing aid programs (quiet vs. noisy situations)
Validate patient's condition and distress to build therapeutic alliance

escalation.rationale_short: To monitor the patient's general and psychological well-being given the severity of his depression and agitation.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor benefit from hearing aids, tinnitus severity, and psychological status.

expected_outcome: Patient reported hearing aids were very helpful, stating they 'absorb the tinnitus' and provide 95% inhibition.
Datalogging confirmed hearing aid use for the entire day, almost exclusively on the first listening program (tinnitus relief).
Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI) score decreased to 24%, indicating significant improvement in quality of life.
Sleep managed successfully using sound enrichment (radio or bedside generator) and medication.
